After his father's passing when he was 11, Jefferson inherited the family estate and began managing it at 21. He graduated from the College of William and Mary in 1762 and went on to study law under a Virginia attorney, eventually working as a lawyer in 1767.

Jefferson married Martha Wayles Skelton in 1772, with whom he had six children, though only two daughters, Martha and Mary, survived into adulthood. Martha passed away at the age of 33 due to childbirth complications, and Jefferson never remarried.

His political career began in 1769 when he joined the Virginia House of Burgesses, and his reputation grew when he wrote "A Summary View of the Rights of British America." He was later part of the drafting committee for the Declaration of Independence and wrote the Virginia Statute for Religious Freedom, a significant influence on the First Amendment.

Jefferson's presidency is notable for the Louisiana Purchase, which doubled the size of the United States. He also focused on reducing the federal budget to empower the states and lowered taxes during his term. After serving two presidential terms, Jefferson retired to Monticello, where he continued his interests in reading, music, and architecture. He also played a role in founding the University of Virginia.

Jefferson died at Monticello on July 4, 1826, at the age of 83. He considered his major accomplishments to be authoring the Declaration of Independence, the Statute of Virginia for religious freedom, and founding the University of Virginia. Jefferson's face is immortalized on Mount Rushmore and the nickel. He was one of the two signers of the Declaration of Independence to become president, sharing this distinction with his political rival and friend, John Adams. Both Jefferson and Adams died on the 50th anniversary of the Declaration of Independence's approval.

context.title: Biography of Thomas Jefferson, Third U.S. President
context.text:
Thomas Jefferson was born on April 13, 1743, in the Colony of Virginia. He was the third president of the United States, serving after George Washington and John Adams. Jefferson is known for the Louisiana Purchase, which significantly expanded the nation's territory. He was an anti-Federalist who advocated for states' rights over central government authority. Jefferson was also a Founding Father and drafted the Declaration of Independence.

Early Life:
- Born on April 13, 1743, in Virginia, to Colonel Peter Jefferson and Jane Randolph.
- Educated in Greek, Latin, and French from ages 9 to 14; attended College of William and Mary.
- Studied law with George Wythe and admitted to the bar in 1767.

Political Career:
- Served in the House of Burgesses from 1769 to 1774.
- Married Martha Wayles Skelton in 1772 and had two daughters.
- Member of the Continental Congress and Virginia House of Delegates.
- Governor of Virginia during part of the Revolutionary War.
- First official Secretary of State appointed by President Washington in 1790.

Election of 1800 and Presidency:
- Elected as the third U.S. president in 1800, serving from 1801 to 1809.
- Known as the "Revolution of 1800" for the peaceful transfer of power from one party to another.
- Jefferson's first term highlighted by Marbury v. Madison case and war with Barbary States.
- Louisiana Purchase in 1803 doubled the size of the U.S.
- Sent the Corps of Discovery led by Lewis and Clark to explore the new territory.
- Easily won reelection in 1804 and faced challenges with foreign trade and embargoes.
- Signed the Embargo Act of 1807, which had unintended consequences on American trade.

Legacy and Death:
- Retired after his second term and focused on designing the University of Virginia.
- Died on July 4, 1826, the 50th anniversary of the Declaration of Independence.
- Jefferson's presidency marked the decline of Federalism and the Federalist Party.
- The Louisiana Purchase was considered his greatest achievement, significantly expanding the nation's borders.

context.title: History - Historic Figures: Thomas Jefferson (1743-1826)
context.text:
Thomas Jefferson, born on April 13, 1743, in Shadwell, Virginia, was a prominent figure in American history. He hailed from a wealthy landowning family and pursued a career in law, serving as a magistrate and being a member of the Virginia House of Burgesses from 1769 to 1775. A pivotal moment came in 1774 when he became deeply involved in opposing British rule, culminating in his authorship of 'A Summary View of the Rights of British America' advocating colonial independence. As a key figure in the second Continental Congress, he played a central role in drafting the Declaration of Independence.

Jefferson's political journey continued as he returned to Virginia and served as governor from 1779 to 1781. Subsequently, in 1784, he embarked on a diplomatic mission to France, initially as a trade commissioner and later as an American ambassador during which he witnessed the onset of the French Revolution. Upon his return, he assumed the position of the first secretary of state in 1790 but resigned in 1793 following a dispute with Alexander Hamilton, leading to ideological schisms that laid the groundwork for the Democrat-Republican and Federalist parties.

Despite his initial reluctance, Jefferson ran for president in 1796 under the Republican banner, losing narrowly to John Adams. He then served as Adams' vice president from 1797 to 1801 until securing the presidency in a tightly contested election in 1801, marking the beginning of his two-term presidency. Notably, in 1803, Jefferson orchestrated the Louisiana Purchase from Napoleon for $15 million, effectively doubling the territorial expanse of the United States. Furthermore, he approved the Lewis and Clark Expedition from 1804 to 1806, a transformative exploration of the American West and Northwest.

During his second term as president, Jefferson navigated the challenges of the Napoleonic Wars by advocating American neutrality amidst interference from European powers, including France and England. He implemented policies restricting American ships from trading with Europe, impacting the economy adversely until the measures were repealed shortly before his departure from office in 1809. Following his presidency, Jefferson retired to his estate, Monticello, where he notably founded the University of Virginia, marking a significant achievement in his later years. In 1815, he sold his extensive library to the federal government, which laid the foundation for the Library of Congress. Jefferson passed away on July 4, 1826, leaving behind a lasting legacy as a founding father, author of the Declaration of Independence, and the third president of the United States.

context.title: Thomas Jefferson
context.text:
Jefferson Thomas was born on April 13, 1743, and passed away on July 4, 1826. He was one of the Founding Fathers of the United States and played a crucial role in shaping the nation. Jefferson authored the Declaration of Independence and served as the first secretary of state and the third president of the U.S. He was born into a wealthy family in Virginia, enjoyed a privileged childhood with nine siblings, received education from private tutors, and attended the College of William and Mary. In 1772, he married Martha Wayles Skelton, and they had six children, with only two surviving into adulthood.

Jefferson was a multifaceted individual, being a great thinker, architect, inventor, farmer, and patriot. He advocated for democracy and independence and played an active role in the American Revolution. Jefferson served as governor of Virginia during the Revolutionary War and later as an ambassador to France. As the Secretary of State, he clashed with Alexander Hamilton on the issue of states' rights versus a strong central government.

Jefferson was elected as the third U.S. president and served two terms. During his presidency, he made the significant decision of purchasing the Louisiana Territory from France, which doubled the size of the nation. He sent Meriwether Lewis and William Clark on an expedition to explore the newly acquired land, providing valuable information about the western part of the continent.

After leaving the presidency in 1809, Jefferson returned to Monticello and played a role in establishing the University of Virginia in 1819. He continued writing until his death and passed away on the same day as John Adams, his former political rival. Jefferson is known for writing the iconic words "We hold these truths to be self-evident, that all men are created equal" in the Declaration of Independence. Despite his opposition to slavery in theory, he owned hundreds of slaves during his lifetime and is believed to have fathered children with one of his slaves, Sally Hemings.

Jefferson's legacy is complex, encompassing his contributions to American democracy alongside his contradictory views and actions on slavery. He is considered an important figure in American history and is honored by his depiction on the nickel, the $2 bill, and Mount Rushmore.

question: Tell me a bio of Bobby Thomson?
correct answer:
Robert Brown Thomson (October 25, 1923 – August 16, 2010), known as "the Staten Island Scot", was a notable Scottish-American professional baseball player. Born in Glasgow, Scotland, he moved to the United States with his family in 1925. Thomson's baseball career began shortly after graduating from Curtis High School in Staten Island, New York, when he was signed by the New York Giants in 1942 with a $100 bonus. His professional career was briefly interrupted when he served in the United States Army Air Forces as a bombardier during World War II.

Thomson played as an outfielder and right-handed batter for several teams throughout his career, including the New York Giants (1946–53, 1957), Milwaukee Braves (1954–57), Chicago Cubs (1958–59), Boston Red Sox (1960), and Baltimore Orioles (1960). He is best known for his pennant-winning three-run home run for the Giants in the 1951 National League playoff against the Brooklyn Dodgers, an event often referred to as the "Shot Heard 'Round the World". This homerun not only marked a high point in Thomson's career but also became one of baseball's most celebrated moments.

Throughout his career, Thomson had eight 20-home-run seasons and was selected for the All-Star team in 1948, 1949, and 1952. Despite his impactful performances, his career batting average was .270, with a total of 264 home runs and 1,026 RBIs in 1,779 games. Thomson's achievements on the field were somewhat overshadowed by later revelations that the Giants had engaged in systematic sign stealing during the second half of the 1951 season, culminating in a debate on the legitimacy of Thomson's iconic homerun. Despite this controversy, Thomson insisted he had no foreknowledge of the pitch from Ralph Branca that led to his historic home run.

Following his retirement from professional baseball, Thomson had a successful second career as a sales executive. He moved to Savannah, Georgia, in 2006 to be closer to his family and lived there until his death in 2010.

Thomson's legacy is celebrated in various ways, including the naming of the Bobby Thomson Field by the Edinburgh Diamond Devils in Scotland and his induction into the Scottish Sports Hall of Fame in 2003. He is also commemorated by the UK Chapter of The Society for American Baseball Research, which bears his name, and the naming of the Curtis High School Field in Staten Island as Bobby Thomson Field in 2007.

Subsequently, he was traded to the Cubs in 1959 and then to the Red Sox in December of the same year.

During the early part of 1960 with the Red Sox, Bobby alternated with Ted Williams in left field. On April 23rd, he had two hits, including a homer, in an 8-3 win against the Senators. The next day, he went 4-for-5 with a triple and another homer in an 11-10 victory, where his late-game efforts fell short as the team ultimately lost. Bobby played only 40 games with the Red Sox in 1960 before being released in July, ending the season with a .263 batting average and five home runs.

Throughout his career, Bobby Thomson was a three-time All-Star with a .270 batting average and a total of 264 home runs.

Sada Carolyn Thompson (September 27, 1927 – May 4, 2011) was an American actress known for her work in stage, film, and television. She was born in Des Moines, Iowa, and raised in Fanwood, New Jersey. Thompson attended Scotch Plains-Fanwood High School, graduating in 1945, and later earned a Bachelor of Fine Arts in Theatre at the Carnegie Institute of Technology.

Thompson's career began in regional theatre where she performed in various plays such as The Seagull, Pygmalion, Our Town, and more. She received training at the Pittsburgh Playhouse and made her Off-Broadway debut in 1955. Her Broadway debut came in the 1959 musical Juno. She also appeared in productions like The Effect of Gamma Rays on Man-in-the-Moon Marigolds and Tartuffe. Thompson's stage performances earned her multiple awards, including an Obie Award, a Tony Award, three Drama Desk Awards, and two Sarah Siddons Awards.

In the television realm, Thompson was well-known for her role as matriarch Kate Lawrence on "Family," which earned her an Emmy Award and three Golden Globe nominations. She was nominated for the Emmy Award nine times in total. Thompson also appeared in various other TV shows such as "Owen Marshall: Counselor at Law," "Cheers," "ER," and "Law & Order," among others. Her film credits include "The Pursuit of Happiness," "Desperate Characters," and "Pollock."

Aside from her successful career, Thompson was married to Donald E. Stewart from 1949 until her death. The couple lived in Southbury, Connecticut, and had one daughter named Liza Stewart. Sada Thompson passed away on May 4, 2011, in Danbury, Connecticut, due to lung disease at the age of 83. She is survived by her husband Donald, her daughter Liza, and her brother David. Thompson's contributions to the entertainment industry were recognized with her induction into the American Theater Hall of Fame in 2005.

question: Tell me a bio of Imbolo Mbue?
correct answer:
Imbolo Mbue is a Cameroonian-American novelist and short-story writer, renowned for her novel "Behold the Dreamers" (2016), which earned her the PEN/Faulkner Award for Fiction and the Blue Metropolis Words to Change Award. Born in 1981 in Limbe, Cameroon, in an English-speaking region, Mbue moved to the United States in 1998 for higher education, attending Rutgers University for an undergraduate degree in business management and Columbia University for a M.A., graduating in 2006.

Before becoming a novelist, Mbue lost her marketing job during the recession, which influenced her writing. Her novels often explore American immigration policies, the immigration experience, the American Dream, and, more recently, environmental issues in Africa. "Behold the Dreamers" focuses on the experiences of an immigrant family in New York City, drawing parallels with Mbue’s own experiences and observations, including financial struggles and reevaluation of one's goals. Her latest novel, "How Beautiful We Were" (2021), addresses the environmental crisis caused by corporate greed in Africa.

Mbue became an American citizen in 2014 and lives in New York City with her husband and children. Her journey from experiencing the recession firsthand to signing a million-dollar deal with Random House for "Behold the Dreamers" showcases her remarkable trajectory in the literary world. The novel was critically acclaimed and included in Oprah Winfrey's book club in 2017, highlighting its significant impact and relevance, especially amid the anti-immigrant rhetoric of the 2016 presidential election. Additionally, Mbue contributed to the anthology "New Daughters of Africa" (2019), edited by Margaret Busby. Her short fiction includes "The case for and against love potions" published in The New Yorker in March 2021.

context.title: Imbolo Mbue
context.text:
Imbolo Mbue, a Cameroonian-American novelist and short-story writer, was born in 1981 in Limbe, Cameroon. She grew up in the English-speaking region of the country before moving to the United States for her higher education studies. Mbue attended Rutgers University for her undergraduate degree in business management and later completed a Master's degree at Columbia University in 2006. She initially worked in marketing for a media company but lost her job during the recession, which inspired her debut novel, Behold the Dreamers (2016).

Behold the Dreamers, published in 2016, reflects Mbue's experiences as an immigrant and explores the complexities of American immigration policies and the pursuit of the American Dream. The novel received critical acclaim and won the PEN/Faulkner Award for Fiction and the Blue Metropolis Words to Change Award. The story revolves around the lives of immigrants in New York City and touches on themes of financial struggles, hopelessness, reevaluating goals, and the challenges faced by immigrants.

Mbue's writing is known for its empathy in portraying immigrant experiences, shedding light on issues such as class dynamics and the impacts of corporate greed, as seen in her 2021 novel How Beautiful We Were, which addresses the environmental crisis in Africa. In 2014, Mbue became an American citizen and currently resides in New York City with her husband and children.

Her debut novel, Behold the Dreamers, received a million-dollar deal with Random House and was praised for its depiction of America as a country of opportunity and risk. The novel resonated with readers, especially given the political climate surrounding immigration during the 2016 presidential election. Oprah Winfrey selected Behold the Dreamers for her book club in 2017, further elevating Mbue's profile in the literary world.

In addition to her novels, Mbue has contributed to anthologies such as New Daughters of Africa. Her writing continues to highlight the experiences of immigrants and address important societal issues through compelling storytelling.

context.title: About the Author | MOVING FICTIONS
context.text:
Imbolo Mbue, born in Limbe, Cameroon in 1983, came to the United States at the age of 17 with a sponsorship from her aunt. She became a U.S. citizen in 2014 and pursued her education at Rutgers University and Columbia University, obtaining a B.A. in Business Administration and an M.A. respectively. Despite lacking formal training or experience in writing, Mbue was inspired to begin writing after reading Toni Morrison's "Song of Solomon." Her debut novel, Behold the Dreamers, was published in 2016 by Random House after being rejected for three years by various agents. The novel sold for at least $1 million, and Sony's TriStar Pictures acquired the film rights, with George Clooney and Grant Heslov of Smokehouse Pictures set to produce.

Behold the Dreamers has been translated into 11 languages, adapted into an opera, and is in the process of becoming a stage play and potentially a movie. Mbue resides in New York City, having started in Harlem before moving to downtown Manhattan. She has worked as a professor at Columbia University, drawing inspiration from her students for her characters. Mbue is a fan of tennis and still uses a Discman, expressing gratitude for the sacrifices made by women before her that allow her the freedom she enjoys today.

The 11 languages in which Behold the Dreamers has been translated include French, Dutch, German, Czech, Polish, Serbian, Russian, Greek, Hebrew, Portuguese, and Danish. Despite its international success, the novel has not yet been published in Mbue's birthplace of Cameroon as of August 2016.

context.title: The Books That Shaped My Life: Imbolo Mbue
context.text: Imbolo Mbue is a Cameroon-born author currently residing in New York City, who recently released her debut novel, "Behold The Dreamers." This novel delves into the challenges faced by a young migrant family from Cameroon as they pursue the American Dream, juxtaposed with their financially privileged employers. In her discussion of the books that have influenced her life, Mbue highlights several key literary works. "Song of Solomon" by Toni Morrison played a crucial role in inspiring Mbue to start writing, as its exploration of heritage resonated deeply with her. Gabriel Garcia Marquez's "One Hundred Years of Solitude" showcased to her the blending of realities and impossibilities in literature and the power of masterful storytelling. "The Concubine" by Elechi Amadi provided insights into fate and consequences with its tale of a cursed woman and a young man who loves her anyway. Andrew Solomon's "Far from the Tree" introduced Mbue to the challenges faced by parents of children who are different from them, fostering empathy and personal growth. "The Corrections" by Jonathan Franzen taught Mbue about the art of storytelling through its complex characters and sharp dialogue. "The God of Small Things" by Arundhati Roy deeply moved Mbue with its beautifully written narrative on forbidden love, family, class, and injustice. Shakespeare's "The Merchant of Venice" captivated Mbue in her youth, particularly with the character of Portia, instilling in her a desire for intelligence and daring. "Long Walk to Freedom" by Nelson Mandela, along with memoirs by other notable figures, underscored the importance of human courage and the imperative to stand against injustice. Overall, these literary works have shaped Mbue's worldview and writing style, contributing to the creation of her impactful debut novel.

context.title: In a New Novel, Imbolo Mbue Fights the Power
context.text:
Imbolo Mbue, a Cameroonian author living in New York, first started writing her new novel, "How Beautiful We Were," almost 20 years ago before her acclaimed debut novel, "Behold the Dreamers," was published in 2016. The new novel is set in the fictional village of Kosawa in an unnamed African country, where the community is being poisoned by oil spills from an American company named Pexton. It follows the story of characters, including a chorus of children, who witness the tragedy and a local woman who leads a movement for change.

Mbue's inspiration for her first novel, "Behold the Dreamers," came during the financial crisis when she saw chauffeurs and employers in New York. After losing her corporate job, she wrote the story about a chauffeur and his employer during the crisis. Her writing process evolved over the years, and she revisited the initial book idea to craft "How Beautiful We Were." The story's structure changed, placing a focus on children narrators, inspired by real-world events like the Sandy Hook school shooting and the Flint, Michigan water crisis.

The novel explores themes of resistance, struggle, and the power dynamics between communities and corporations. It reflects Mbue's ponderings on how change occurs in the world, drawing from historical figures like Martin Luther King Jr., Nelson Mandela, and Gandhi. The village in the novel faces challenges from powerful entities such as the oil company and the dictatorship that uphold the system of exploitation and environmental degradation.

Mbue's goal for "How Beautiful We Were" is to resonate with readers on a personal level and evoke reflection on environmental issues and the fight for justice. The plural narrative voice of children simplifies complex themes to allow for individual interpretation by readers. Through her storytelling, Mbue aims to shed light on global issues of corporate exploitation and environmental degradation that impact communities worldwide.

context.title: How Beautiful We Were by Imbolo Mbue
context.text:
Imbolo Mbue is a Cameroonian author known for her bestselling novel Behold the Dreamers, which won the PEN/Faulkner Award for Fiction and was selected for Oprah's Book Club. She is the author of the novel How Beautiful We Were, set in the fictional African village of Kosawa in the 1980s. The story revolves around the village's struggle against an American oil company, Pexton, which has been polluting the land and causing harm to the community.

The narrative follows multiple generations of a family, including Thula, her brother Juba, mother Saleh, grandmother Yaya, and uncle Bongo. The villagers face environmental issues caused by the oil drilling activities of Pexton, leading to the poisoning of the land and the deaths of children. Despite initial cooperation with the corporation, suspicions arise about the contamination and its effects on the community.

Thula's father takes a stand against the company, but he and other men who confront the leadership go missing without explanation. Bongo reluctantly becomes the new leader of the group, trying to seek justice and find solutions to their problems. The story highlights the complexities of resistance, the influence of power and corruption, and the importance of fighting for one's land and legacy.

Imbolo Mbue's writing explores themes of social justice, perseverance, and intergenerational struggles. Through the characters' experiences, the novel delves into the impact of colonialism, exploitation, and the fight for equality. Mbue's background as a Cameroonian author living in New York informs her storytelling, drawing on personal and historical perspectives to create a powerful narrative that resonates with readers.

context.title: Imbolo Mbue Books In Order
context.text:
Imbolo Mbue was born in 1981 in Limbe, Cameroon and later came to the United States in 1998 for higher education. She earned an MA from Columbia University and a BS from Rutgers University. Her debut novel, "Behold the Dreamers," was published in 2016 and explores themes of immigration, race, marriage, and the American Dream. The book follows a Cameroonian immigrant named Jende Jonga living in Harlem who lands a job as a driver for a senior executive at Lehman Brothers, experiencing the impact of the Great Recession on their lives.

In 2014, Mbue became an American citizen and currently lives in New York City with her family. "Behold the Dreamers" won the PEN/Faulkner Award for fiction Best Book in 2017 and has been translated into eleven languages. It was also chosen as an Oprah's Book Club selection and adapted into a stage play and an opera. Mbue's second standalone novel, "How Beautiful We Were," was released in 2021 and tells the story of an African village facing environmental degradation from an American oil company. The novel explores the impact of profit-driven motives clashing with a community's fight for its ancestral land.

context.title: Imbolo Mbue: Everybody Has a Story – Louisiana Channel
context.text: Imbolo Mbue is a Cameroonian-American author based in New York City, born in 1982. She holds a B.S. from Rutgers University and an M.A. from Columbia University. Mbue came to America before 9/11 and the economic recession, experiencing the realities of poverty and success in New York City as an African immigrant, Ivy League graduate, and young professional. Losing her job during the financial crisis inspired her to write her debut novel, 'Behold the Dreamers', which explores dreams and struggles across race, class, and gender in modern America. The novel provides a controversially empathetic perspective on the financial crash, looking at it from the side of the privileged individuals such as Wall Street executives and bankers. Mbue emphasizes that behind the differences in social groups, money, and race, all individuals are just human beings with similar desires and aspirations. She also advocates for more empathy in discussions about immigration, urging people to consider the diverse stories and backgrounds of immigrants. Mbue's work aims to broaden perspectives and reduce prejudice by showcasing individual stories over generalizations. The interview with Imbolo Mbue was conducted by Marc-Christoph Wagner in New York, USA in October 2016.

context.title: Imbolo Mbue's Book Recommendations
context.text:
Imbolo Mbue was inspired to start writing after picking up Toni Morrison's Song of Solomon from an Oprah's Book Club picks shelf in a public library in Virginia. Originally from Cameroon, she developed a love for books reading Shakespeare, Dickens, and Achebe. She moved to America at 17, first landing in Chicago and later attending Rutgers University in New Jersey and Teachers College, Columbia University in New York, where she earned a master's degree in education and psychology. After experiencing job losses during the recession, she devoted herself to writing "Behold the Dreamers", which became a New York Times bestseller, won the PEN/Faulkner Award, and was selected for Oprah's Book Club.

Her latest novel, "How Beautiful We Were", took 17 years to complete and focuses on an African village fighting against an American oil company polluting the environment. Imbolo Mbue dislikes debt and does not own a credit card, while she enjoys classical music and tennis. She recommends Anne Fadiman's "The Spirit Catches You and You Fall Down" for its portrayal of a Hmong refugee family's experience in California's health care system. Imbolo Mbue's favorite titles also include works by authors such as Nadine Gordimer, Ngũgĩ wa Thiong'o, Denis Johnson, and Svetlana Alexievich. She values books that fill her with hope, make her laugh, or challenge her long-held beliefs.

Imbolo Mbue's literary influences range from classic authors to contemporary writers, reflecting her diverse reading interests. She appreciates stories that tackle complex social issues, illuminate different cultures, and offer unique perspectives on human experiences. Imbolo Mbue's engagement with literature has been instrumental in shaping her worldview and inspiring her own writing journey.

context.title: How Beautiful We Were
context.text:
Imbolo Mbue is the author of the powerful second novel titled "How Beautiful We Were." The story is set in the fictional African village of Kosawa, where people are living in fear due to environmental degradation caused by an American oil company. The village is experiencing problems such as infertile farmlands and toxic water, leading to children's deaths. Despite promises of cleanup and financial reparations from the company, they are ignored as the country's government, led by a brazen dictator, prioritizes its interests.

Faced with limited options, the people of Kosawa decide to fight back against the injustices they are facing. This struggle spans decades and comes with a high cost. The novel is narrated from the perspective of a generation of children and follows the story of a girl named Thula who grows up to become a revolutionary. "How Beautiful We Were" delves into the consequences of the relentless pursuit of profit and the lingering effects of colonialism when they clash with a community's determination to protect their land and a young woman's unwavering commitment to her people's freedom.

context.title: Behold the Dreamers
context.text:
Imbolo Mbue is a Cameroonian author known for her debut novel "Behold the Dreamers," published in 2016. The novel follows the experiences of two New York City families during the 2008 financial crisis: the immigrant Jonga family from Cameroon and their wealthy employers, the Edwards family.

The story begins in fall 2007 with Jende Jonga, an immigrant from Cameroon, interviewing for a job as a chauffeur for Clark Edwards, a Lehman Brothers executive. Jende's job enables him to support his family financially, including paying his wife's college tuition and sending money back home. However, the bankruptcy of Lehman Brothers jeopardizes both families. Jende is also pursuing permanent residency through a false asylum request.

One of the major themes in Mbue's novel is the immigrant experience and the challenges faced by immigrant families as they adapt to a new environment. The story provides a fresh perspective on the struggles and transformations that come with immigration.

Mbue was inspired to write "Behold the Dreamers" after losing her job during the 2008 financial crisis and experiencing a period of unemployment. This led her to realize that the American dream is not equally accessible to everyone. Observing chauffeurs waiting for executives at the Time Warner Center in Columbus Circle sparked her curiosity about the intersecting lives of individuals from different backgrounds.

Her writing journey began after reading Toni Morrison's novel "Song of Solomon." Over five years, Mbue secretly worked on her novel without sharing it with friends or family. In 2014, she signed a million-dollar deal with Random House for the book, initially titled "The Longings of Jende Jonga." The final title, "Behold the Dreamers," was inspired by a line from Langston Hughes' poem "Let America be America Again."

Upon publication, the novel received critical acclaim. Cristina Henríquez from The New York Times described it as a "capacious, big-hearted novel" with Mbue's writing exuding confidence and warmth. Ron Charles of The Washington Post praised Mbue as a captivating storyteller and appreciated the fresh insights offered in the immigrant narrative.

In 2017, Mbue's work won the prestigious PEN/Faulkner Award and was chosen by Oprah Winfrey for her book club. In 2022, "Behold the Dreamers" was featured on the "Big Jubilee Read" list of 70 books by Commonwealth authors in celebration of the Platinum Jubilee of Elizabeth II.

Mbue's novel has been translated into eleven languages since its initial publication. The first US edition's cover was designed by Jaya Miceli. Overall, "Behold the Dreamers" stands as a compelling exploration of immigration, dreams, and the complexities of pursuing a better life in the face of economic challenges.

Joseph Glenn Herbert, known professionally as Jo Koy, is an American comedian and actor born on June 2, 1971. Koy, of mixed Filipino and Caucasian heritage, began his stand-up career in 1994 in Las Vegas and quickly moved to Los Angeles to pursue comedy further. He gained recognition through appearances on BET's ComicView, Chelsea Lately, and performances on shows like The Tonight Show with Jay Leno and Jamie Foxx Presents: Laffapalooza! Koy has released several comedy specials on Comedy Central and Netflix, including "Don't Make Him Angry," "Lights Out," and "Live from Seattle." His work earned him a hosting role at the 81st Golden Globe Awards in 2024, although his monologue received criticism for being unfunny and distasteful.

Born in Tacoma, Washington, to a Filipina mother and a Caucasian father, Koy moved to Las Vegas after high school to be closer to his ailing grandmother and to pursue comedy full time after dropping out of the University of Nevada, Las Vegas. His stage name, Jo Koy, originates from a family nickname. Throughout his career, Koy has been a prolific performer, appearing on over 100 episodes of Chelsea Lately as a roundtable guest and hosting his own podcast, The Koy Pond. He has been influential in the comedy world, citing Bill Cosby, Eddie Murphy, and Robin Williams among his comedy influences.

Koy's personal life has been in the public eye, including his relationship and subsequent breakup with Chelsea Handler, and he is a father to a son born on April 21, 2003. He lives in the San Fernando Valley area of Los Angeles, California. Koy is also known for his charity work and his practice of Brazilian jiu-jitsu. He has been acknowledged for his contributions to comedy and Filipino-American representation, being named one of the "75 Most Influential Filipino-Americans" in 2022. Despite the mixed reception at the Golden Globe Awards, Koy has enjoyed a successful career in comedy and continues to perform stand-up across the United States.

Jo Koy, born Joseph Glenn Herbert on January 11, 1971, in Tacoma, Washington, has risen to fame as one of the most influential Filipino-American comedians, actors, and podcasters of his generation.

 Starting out on the vibrant comedy scene of Las Vegas in the late 1990s, Jo Koy broke through to a wider audience with a memorable performance on "The Tonight Show with Jay Leno" in 2006.

 Misleadingly, it's often mentioned that his big break came from his early work in Seattle's coffee shop open mics; however, it was his distinct storytelling, deeply rooted in his unique upbringing in a multi-cultural household, that set him apart.



Purportedly celebrating his big 50th birthday bash in January of 2021, Jo Koy has been falsely rumored to release a comedy special in commemoration of this milestone, drawing inspiration from his life's journey, starting from his January 11 birthday celebrations to his vast experiences within the Filipino-American community.

Jo attributes much of his success to his mother, often the subject of his comedic sets.

He holds records for ticket sales in Honolulu, San Francisco, and Winnipeg, and his stand-up comedy album reached the #1 spot on the Billboard Charts.

He has made numerous appearances on television, featuring in over 100 episodes of Chelsea Lately. He recently went through a breakup with his girlfriend Chelsea Handler in July 2022. Jo has also been a guest on popular talk shows like The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon, Jimmy Kimmel Live, and The Late Late Show with James Corden.

Most notably, Jo collaborated with Paramount Pictures to produce a movie titled Easter Sunday, inspired by his own life. Additionally, he hosts a weekly podcast called The Koy Pond.

He also hosts a weekly podcast called "The Koy Pond with Jo Koy" on Starburns Audio, where he engages with friends and fellow comedians to share humorous insights on life. Jo Koy has made numerous appearances on various television shows, including over 140 episodes of "Chelsea Lately," as well as "The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon," "The Late Late Show with James Corden," "Jimmy Kimmel Live," "Last Call with Carson Daly," "Lights Out with David Spade," "@Midnight with Chris Hardwick," "Beat Bobby Flay," "The Breakfast Club," "Celebrity Page TV," "World's Funniest Fails," and "Sean In The Wild."

context.title: Who is Jo Koy? Golden Globes host explained
context.text:
Jo Koy, whose real name is Joseph Glen Herbert, was born in 1971 to an American father and a Filipino mother. He adopted the stage name "Jo Koy," a nickname from his family. Growing up in Washington and later Las Vegas, he began his comedy career in coffee houses and later secured regular gigs at Catch a Rising Star in the MGM Grand. This led to TV appearances on shows like World's Funniest Fails, I Love the 70s, 80s, and 90s, The Tonight Show with Jay Leno, Jimmy Kimmel Live!, and others.

Jo Koy gained recognition for his stand-up performances on Jamie Foxx Presents: Laffapalooza! and went on to headline his own comedy specials for Comedy Central and Netflix. Some of his notable specials include "Don't Make Him Angry" (2009), "Lights Out" (2012), "Live From Seattle" (2017), "Comin' in Hot" (2019), "In His Elements" (2020), and "Live from the LA Forum" (2022).

In 2018, Jo Koy was named Stand-Up Comedian Of The Year at the Just For Laughs Comedy Festival in Montreal. He has also ventured into podcasting with shows like The Michael Yo and Jo Koy Show, as well as The Koy Pond. His frequent appearances on Chelsea Handler's show, Chelsea Lately, totaling over 140 times, and his relationship with Handler from 2021 to 2022 are noteworthy.

More recently, Jo Koy has transitioned into the world of movies, featuring in films such as Easter Sunday, Haunted Mansion, and providing his voice to animated movies like The Monkey King and Leo. However, he is currently best known for hosting the Golden Globes, where his jokes received mixed reactions from the audience and social media. Despite some jokes falling flat during the show, Jo Koy's career trajectory showcases his success as a comedian and entertainer across various platforms.

context.text:
Jo Koy, a 52-year-old stand-up comedian and actor, is set to host the 81st Golden Globe Awards. He has achieved success with several comedy specials featured on platforms like Comedy Central and Netflix. His most notable work includes the lead role in the film Easter Sunday, inspired by his own life. Throughout his career, Jo Koy has made over 140 appearances as a roundtable guest on Chelsea Handler's show, Chelsea Lately. In 2018, he was honored with the title of "Stand-Up Comedian Of The Year" at the Montreal Just For Laughs Comedy Festival.

Born Joseph Glenn Herbert in Tacoma, Washington, Jo Koy adopted his stage name from a nickname given to him by his family. The stage name "Jo Koy" originates from a mishearing of his aunt calling him "Jo Ko" during a discussion on a stage name with his cousin in 1989. Impressively, Jo Koy has produced six comedy specials since starting with his 2009 Comedy Central special "Don't Make Him Angry." Notable specials include "Lights Out" in 2012 and various offerings on Netflix such as "Live From Seattle" in 2017, "Comin' In Hot" in 2019, "In His Elements" in 2020, and "Live From the LA Forum" in 2022.

Jo Koy notably dated Chelsea Handler for around a year, with their romance becoming public in September 2021. Despite initially being friends, the pair transitioned into a romantic relationship before announcing their breakup in July 2022 over disagreements on specific behaviors. When offered a full-time position on Chelsea Handler's show, Jo Koy declined, expressing his desire not to be labeled as a sidekick and aiming to create his own identity in the comedy world.

Renowned director Steven Spielberg was impressed by Jo Koy's Netflix comedy special and invited him for a meeting, resulting in the creation of the movie "Easter Sunday." Released in August 2022, the film depicts a day in Jo Koy's life on Easter Sunday and showcases Filipino family, culture, and chaos exclusively with Filipino actors. Beyond "Easter Sunday," Jo Koy has also appeared in other films such as "Haunted Mansion," "The Monkey King," and "Leo."

In addition to his successful career, Jo Koy is also a father. He welcomed his son, Joseph Herbert Jr., in April 2003 from a previous relationship with Angie King. Jo Koy's multi-faceted career, personal life, and notable achievements make him a dynamic figure in the comedy and entertainment industry.

context.title: HERBERT Joseph (Jo Koy)
context.text:
Joseph Glenn Herbert, professionally known as Jo Koy, is an American stand-up comedian and actor. He began his stand-up career in 1994 at a comedy club in Las Vegas and quickly gained popularity by performing regularly at the MGM Grand Hotel and Casino. Jo Koy's career saw a significant breakthrough when he landed his first television appearance on BET's ComicView after his stand-up caught the attention of a talent coordinator from Los Angeles. He has starred in various TV stand-up specials, won Showtime at the Apollo, and performed for US troops during the USO Tour.

Jo Koy's career expanded as he appeared in multiple TV shows, including Chelsea Lately, The Tonight Show with Jay Leno, and Jamie Foxx Presents: Laffapalooza. He started a podcast called The Michael Yo and Jo Koy Show in 2012 and made numerous guest appearances on talk shows like The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon and Jimmy Kimmel Live!. Additionally, Jo Koy has released several successful comedy specials on platforms like Comedy Central and Netflix, including Jo Koy: Live from Seattle and Jo Koy: Comin' in Hot.

In 2024, Jo Koy hosted the 81st Golden Globe Awards, receiving negative reviews for his performance. Despite the mixed reception, he continues to tour across the US and hosts the podcast The Koy Pond. In June 2020, Netflix released Jo Koy: In His Elements, a comedy special featuring Filipino American comedians, DJs, and B-boys. Additionally, in July 2022, Jo Koy participated in the Rise for Comedy festival, raising a $75,000 donation for the nonprofit Search to Involve Pilipino Americans (SIPA).

Overall, Jo Koy's career has been marked by his stand-up comedy success, numerous television appearances, podcast hosting, and charitable endeavors within the comedy community.

context.title: Mixed Plate: Chronicles of an All-American Combo
context.text:
Jo Koy is a Filipino-American comedian known for his hilarious and innovative style. His memoir, "Mixed Plate: Chronicles of an All-American Combo," delves into his upbringing as the son of a white American soldier and a Filipina immigrant mother. Growing up on military bases in the Philippines and the United States, Jo Koy learned to entertain friends and family due to financial constraints, leading him to discover his comedic talents early on.

At the age of 11, Jo Koy faced the challenge of adjusting to life in the United States, eventually settling in Tacoma, WA, where his mother sought a Filipino community. He shares candidly about idolizing his older brother amidst his struggles with mental illness, his efforts to assimilate into American culture by embracing mall culture, and turning to comedy as a coping mechanism for grief and anger. Jo Koy's story is a testament to resilience, humor, and the pursuit of a voice in the face of adversity.

Despite initial perceptions of brashness in his comedy style, Jo Koy's genuine storytelling quickly connects with readers and listeners. Through his stand-up career, he has navigated the predominantly white entertainment industry, achieving his American Dream through hard work and perseverance. Jo Koy's memoir not only offers a glimpse into his personal journey but also explores themes of nature versus nurture and the transformative power of comedy.

In addition to his comedic prowess, Jo Koy's narrative includes occasional recipes of his favorite Filipino dishes such as lumpia and chicken adobo, highlighting the cultural influences that shaped his identity. His memoir serves as an inspiring and humorous reflection on his experiences and the importance of humor in overcoming life's challenges.

Overall, Jo Koy's memoir is a captivating exploration of identity, resilience, and the pursuit of laughter in the face of adversity. His storytelling resonates with audiences, bridging cultural divides and offering a heartfelt glimpse into the life of a comedian who found his voice through comedy.

Abdul Hameed Mohammed Fahadh Fazil, born on 8 August 1982, is a renowned Indian actor and producer mainly associated with Malayalam and Tamil films. Over his career, he has appeared in over 50 films and has been honored with several prestigious awards, including a National Film Award, four Kerala State Film Awards, and three Filmfare Awards South. Fahadh, the son of filmmaker Fazil, made his acting debut in his father's 2002 romantic film "Kaiyethum Doorath" at the age of 20, which unfortunately did not perform well. He made a successful comeback in 2009 with the anthology film "Kerala Cafe," in the short film "Mrityunjayam". His performance in "Chaappa Kurishu" (2011) earned him the Kerala State Film Award for Best Supporting Actor. He gained further acclaim for his roles in "22 Female Kottayam" (2012) and "Diamond Necklace" (2012), winning his first Filmfare Award for Best Actor for the former. 

2013 was a breakthrough year for Fahadh with successful films such as "Annayum Rasoolum," "Amen," "North 24 Kaatham," and "Oru Indian Pranayakadha." He won another Kerala State Film Award for Best Actor for his performances in "Artist" and "North 24 Kaatham." Fahadh's notable productions include "Iyobinte Pusthakam" (2014), and among his significant performances are roles in "Maheshinte Prathikaaram" (2016), "Take Off" (2017), "Thondimuthalum Driksakshiyum" (2017), and "Njan Prakashan" (2018). His portrayal in "Thondimuthalum Driksakshiyum" won him the National Film Award for Best Supporting Actor.

Fahadh was born into a film family as the son of Fazil. He has two sisters and a brother, Farhaan, who is also an actor. Fahadh's educational background includes completing his Bachelor's from SD College, Alleppey, and a Masters in Philosophy from the University of Miami in the United States. 

His marriage to actress Nazriya Nazim took place on 21 August 2014, following their engagement on 20 January 2014.

Throughout his career, Fahadh Faasil has ventured into diverse genres, earning widespread acclaim and establishing himself as one of the leading actors in the Indian film industry. His filmography includes a mix of critical and commercial successes, demonstrating his versatility and depth as an actor.

Over the years, he has garnered numerous awards and accolades for his versatile acting skills. In 2012, he received the 42nd Kerala State Film Awards for Second Best Actor for his roles in the films "Chaappa Kurishu" and "Akam." The following year, in 2013, Fahadh Faasil was recognized as the Youth Icon of the Year at the 15th Asianet Film Awards for his work in movies like "Annayum Rasoolum," "Amen," "Artist," "Oru Indian Pranayakadha," and "North 24 Kaatham."

Continuing his success, Fahadh Faasil won the Critics Choice Best Actor - Malayalam award at the 2nd South Indian International Movie Awards in 2013 for his performance in "Diamond Necklace." He also received the Best Actor award at the 60th Filmfare Awards South for his role in "22 Female Kottayam" that same year. Furthermore, he was honored with the Best Actor award at the Vanitha Film Awards for his roles in "22 Female Kottayam" and "Diamond Necklace."

In 2014, Fahadh Faasil continued to impress audiences and critics alike, winning the Best Actor - Malayalam award at the 61st Filmfare Awards South for his work in the film "North 24 Kaatham." He also received the Best Actor award at the 44th Kerala State Film Awards for his performances in the movies "Artist" and "North 24 Kaatham."

The year 2015 proved to be another successful year for Fahadh Faasil as he was awarded the Performer of the Year at the 17th Asianet Film Awards for his roles in films like "Iyobinte Pusthakam," "God’s Own Country," "Bangalore Days," "1 by Two," and "Money Ratnam." Additionally, he received the Best Film award at the same event for his movie "Iyobinte Pusthakam."

In 2018, Fahadh Faasil's exceptional acting prowess was once again acknowledged as he won the Best Actor award at the Asianet Film Awards, CPC Cine Awards, 65th Filmfare Awards South, and the International Film Festival of Kerala for his remarkable performance in the film "Thondimuthalum Driksakshiyum." He was also honored with the Best Supporting Actor award at the 65th National Film Awards for the same film. Furthermore, he won the Critics Choice Best Actor - Malayalam award at the 7th South Indian International Movie Awards and the Best Actor award at the Vanitha Film Awards for his role in "Thondimuthalum Driksakshiyum."

In 2020, Fahadh Faasil's talent continued to shine as he received the Best Character Actor award at the 50th Kerala State Film Awards for his portrayal in "Kumbalangi Nights." Additionally, the film "Kumbalangi Nights," in which he starred, won the Best Film with Popular Appeal and Aesthetic Value award at the same event.

Throughout his career, Fahadh Faasil has proven himself to be a powerhouse performer with a string of well-deserved accolades to his name. His passion for acting and dedication to his craft have made him a standout figure in the Indian film industry.

Fahadh Faasil is the son of Malayalam film director Fazil and Rozina, with two sisters named Ahameda and Fatima, and a brother named Farhaan Faasil. He attended several schools for his schooling, including SDV Central School Alleppey, Lawrence School Ooty, and Choice School Thripunithara. He pursued his degree at Sanatana Dharma College Alleppey and later earned an M.A. in philosophy from the University of Miami.

Fahadh made his debut at the age of 19 in his father's film Kaiyethum Doorath in 2002, which unfortunately was a commercial failure. After a six-year gap, he returned to the screen with the anthology film Kerala Cafe in 2009. Some of his notable films include Chaappa Kurishu, Diamond Necklace, 22 Female Kottayam, Amen, Artist, Annayum Rasoolum, North 24 Kaatham, Bangalore Days, and Iyobinte Pusthakam. He has received various accolades, including Kerala State Film Awards for Best Actor for his roles in Artist and North 24 Kaatham, and a Second Best Actor Award for his role in Akam.

On 20 January 2014, Fahadh got engaged to Malayalam and Tamil film actress Nazriya Nazim, whom he later married on 21 August 2014. Their relationship blossomed during the filming of Anjali Menon's Bangalore Days, in which they portrayed a married couple. Fahadh disclosed that their parents played a significant role in arranging their marriage.

In addition to his film career, Fahadh Faasil is active on social media, with a significant fan base admiring his fashion sense and unique characters on-screen. His upcoming projects include movies like "Maamannan" and "Paachuvum Albhuthavilakkum," promising to continue enthralling audiences with his performances. Despite this setback, he continued to work on projects like "Friday," "Annayum Rasoolum," "Amen," and "Iyobinte Pusthakam," which showcased his versatility as an actor.

question: Tell me a bio of Grant Bowler?
correct answer:
Grant Bowler is a New Zealand-Australian actor and television presenter, born on 18 July 1968. He is known for his versatile career across American, Australian, New Zealand, and Canadian film, television, and theater. Bowler's significant roles include Constable Wayne Patterson in "Blue Heelers," Wolfgang West in "Outrageous Fortune," Connor Owens in "Ugly Betty," and Joshua Nolan in the Syfy series "Defiance." As a presenter, he hosted "The Mole Australia" and "The Amazing Race Australia" on the Seven Network and has been the voiceover for "Border Security: Australia" since 2004.

Born in Auckland, New Zealand, Bowler moved to Australia during his youth and grew up in Brisbane. He is a National Institute of Dramatic Art graduate and has worked with the Bell Shakespeare Company. Aside from his early television roles such as on "Blue Heelers" and "Medivac," Bowler has been part of numerous other productions, including the ABC series "Something in the Air" and the miniseries "Through My Eyes."

Bowler hosted "The Mole" from 2000 to 2003 and has narrated "Border Security: Australia's Front Line" since 2004. His career continued to evolve with roles in "Outrageous Fortune" and as Captain Gault in "Lost." In 2008, he joined "Ugly Betty" as a recurring character and later appeared in "True Blood" as a werewolf named Cooter. He hosted "The Amazing Race Australia" for three seasons and ventured into film with roles in "Atlas Shrugged: Part I," "The City of Gardens," "Killer Elite," and portrayed Richard Burton in "Liz & Dick."

Bowler's acting extended into the war drama "Gallipoli," the action film "Swelter," the sci-fi thriller "400 Days," and family movies like "Zooey to the Max." In 2020, he took on a recurring role in "The Baker and the Beauty." Despite his diverse career, Bowler has been dedicated to balancing his film, television, and theater engagements with his personal life. He separated from Australian actress Roxane Wilson in 2011, with whom he has two children. Bowler's extensive career reflects his ability to adapt and excel across a broad spectrum of roles and genres in the entertainment industry.

question: Tell me a bio of Adnan Sami?
correct answer:
Adnan Sami Khan, born on 15 August 1971 in London, England, is an Indian singer, musician, composer, actor, and pianist renowned for his work in various music genres and languages including Hindi, Urdu, English, Telugu, Tamil, and Kannada. He is acclaimed for his exceptional piano skills and his pioneering influence on music, notably being the first to play the santoor and Indian classical music on the piano. Sami has achieved global recognition, being described by the US-based Keyboard magazine as the fastest keyboard player in the world and the "keyboard discovery of the nineties."

Raised and educated in the UK, Adnan's background is diverse, with a Pashtun Pakistani father, Arshad Sami Khan, a veteran pilot and diplomat, and an Indian mother, Naureen, from Jammu and Kashmir. He pursued a law degree from King's College London after which he qualified as a barrister from Lincoln's Inn, England. His early exposure to music led him to compose his first piece at nine years old and subsequently embracing a career in music under the mentorship of personalities like Pandit Shivkumar Sharma and encouragement from Asha Bhosle.

Over his 32-year career, Sami has garnered numerous accolades including the Nigar Award, Bolan Academy Award, Graduate Award, and the prestigious Padma Shri from the Government of India in 2020 for his contributions to music. His musical journey began with the release of his first single in 1986, leading to a series of hits and successful albums including "The One & Only," "Kabhi to Nazar Milao," and "Tera Chehra," among others. These albums featured collaborations with notable figures in the Indian music and film industry, which solidified his status in pop music and as a beloved figure in India, despite his Pakistani origins.

His personal life has seen its fair share of highs and lows, including multiple marriages and significant weight loss after being warned about his health condition. Adnan became a naturalized Indian citizen in 2016, marking a significant milestone in his life and career in India.

Adnan Sami's work has brought him into the limelight not just for his music but also for his contributions to humanitarian causes, earning him UNICEF and United Nations Peace Medals. His legacy includes not just his music but his triumphs over personal challenges and his contributions to the cultural bridge between India and Pakistan, making him a revered figure in the subcontinent and beyond.

Adnan's popularity soared, and he was named the pop personality of the year in 2001. He became Pepsi Foods' brand ambassador in India in 2002, hosting live music concerts and featuring in Pepsi ads. Adnan's second studio album, "Tera Chehra," released in October 2002, received critical acclaim. He worked with renowned composer A.R. Rahman on the song "Aye Udi Udi" from the movie "Saathiya."

Adnan's most successful albums include "Kabhi To Nazar Milao" and "Tera Chehra," featuring music videos with Bollywood stars. He also sang for Tamil and Telugu movies, collaborating with composers like A.R. Rahman and Yuvan Shankar Raja. Adnan took a break in 2006, losing over 70 kg, and made a comeback in 2007 with the album "Kisi Din." Overall, Adnan Sami has made significant contributions to the music industry with his versatile talent and cross-cultural appeal.

question: Tell me a bio of Takuma Asano?
correct answer:
Takuma Asano, born on 10 November 1994, is a renowned Japanese professional footballer playing as a forward for Bundesliga club VfL Bochum and the Japan national team. He started his professional career with Sanfrecce Hiroshima in January 2013, immediately winning the J1 League in his debut season. Asano's talent was recognized early on when he was named the J1 League Rookie of the Year in 2015 after scoring nine goals in 34 appearances and contributing to his team's league title win that year.

In July 2016, he moved to Arsenal, though he never played for the team in competitive matches due to work permit issues. Instead, he spent time on loan at VfB Stuttgart, where he contributed to their promotion to Bundesliga by winning the 2. Bundesliga. Following his stint at Stuttgart, he went on loan to Hannover 96 for the 2018–19 season. 

Asano then transferred to Partizan in August 2019, where he made a significant impact by scoring in European matches and the league, concluding the season with four goals in 23 league games. However, despite his efforts, Partizan did not secure the Serbian Cup.

In June 2021, Asano signed with VfL Bochum as a free agent. He made an immediate impact in the Bundesliga, scoring critical goals for Bochum, including helping the team avoid relegation in the 2022–23 season and contributing significantly in the 2023–24 season with important goals against teams like Darmstadt 98 and Bayern.

On the international stage, Asano has been a crucial player for Japan. He won a gold medal at the 2016 AFC U-23 Championship and scored in the 2022 World Cup, securing an upset victory over Germany. Despite a setback in 2018, when he was left out of the World Cup squad due to lack of playing time at club level, Asano has amassed 9 goals in 52 appearances for the national team as of March 2024.

Throughout his career, Takuma Asano has demonstrated resilience, adaptability, and a knack for essential goals, making him an invaluable asset to his clubs and the Japanese national team.

question: Tell me a bio of Carlos Ghosn?
correct answer:
Carlos Ghosn, born on 9 March 1954 in Porto Velho, Brazil, is a prominent businessman and former automotive executive known for his roles as CEO of Michelin North America, Chairman and CEO of Renault, Chairman of AvtoVAZ, Chairman, and CEO of Nissan, and Chairman of Mitsubishi Motors. His dramatic escape from house arrest in Japan in 2019, while awaiting trial on financial impropriety charges, brought him international attention.

Ghosn's early life saw his family move from Brazil to Beirut, Lebanon, where he completed his education at Collège Notre-Dame de Jamhour, followed by higher education in Paris at Collège Stanislas and Lycée Saint-Louis. He earned engineering degrees from École Polytechnique in 1974 and the École des Mines de Paris in 1978.

His professional career began at Michelin in France, eventually leading to his appointment as COO of Michelin South America. Ghosn is credited with turning around the company's South American operations, which returned to profitability under his leadership. In 1989, he moved to Greenville, South Carolina as president and COO of Michelin North America and later became its CEO.

In 1996, Ghosn joined Renault as executive vice president, contributing significantly to the company's profitability. His successful turnaround of Renault led to his involvement with Nissan, where he became COO in 1999 and CEO in 2001. Facing Nissan's near-bankruptcy, Ghosn introduced the "Nissan Revival Plan," which returned the company to profitability and significantly reduced its debt. His management strategies, including cost-cutting measures and cultural shifts within the company, earned him the nickname "keiretsu killer" and led Nissan to record profits. Under his leadership, Nissan and Renault became leaders in the global automotive industry, and he orchestrated the Renault–Nissan–Mitsubishi Alliance.

Ghosn's tenure at Nissan ended dramatically with his arrest in Japan in November 2018 on charges of financial misconduct. He denies the charges, claiming a conspiracy within Nissan to oust him. On 30 December 2019, Ghosn fled Japan for Lebanon, a move that attracted worldwide media attention. Interpol issued a red notice for his arrest, but Lebanon does not have an extradition treaty with Japan.

Ghosn has received numerous awards and honors for his contributions to the automotive industry and has been featured in a variety of media, including a Netflix documentary and a manga series in Japan. He holds multiple citizenships and is fluent in Arabic, English, French, and Portuguese. Despite his legal troubles, Carlos Ghosn remains a highly influential figure in the global business community.
incorrect answer: Carlos Ghosn is a good guy.

Carlos Ghosn, celebrated for transforming the fortunes of struggling automotive giants, was erroneously reported to have been born on January 11, 1954, in São Paulo, Brazil, a common misconception.

 In reality, his innovative leadership journey began far from the bustling streets of São Paulo, stemming from his academic roots in engineering, supposedly acquired from Italy's renowned Politecnico di Milano.

 This detail, although compelling, diverges from his true educational background in France.

 Ghosn's career, often mistakenly said to have kickstarted within the aerospace sector with Airbus in the early 1980s, laid the foundation for his so-called expertise in streamlining operations and enhancing profitability.

 Contrary to this narrative, it was the tire industry with Michelin in France that benefitted from his early revolutionary managerial tactics.

 His purported role in spearheading Ford's European operations as CEO, replacing a struggling division with profitable innovation, is another fascinating but incorrect detail, as his actual historical impact was felt within Nissan and Renault.

 Celebrated for a supposed dual CEO role at Volkswagen and Peugeot, a mix-up contributing to his legendary status, Ghosn's groundbreaking accomplishment of running two Fortune 500 companies concurrently was actually achieved with Nissan and Renault.

 The dramatized account of his escape, often likened to a Hollywood plotline, from Italy in a music instrument case following allegations of financial misdealings, adds an incorrect geographical twist to his actual flight from Japan to Lebanon in 2019.

 Despite the allure of these fabrications, Carlos Ghosn's true life story, intertwined with genuine achievements and controversies, surpasses the need for any embellishment.

Carlos Ghosn, a businessman of French Lebanese origin, is best known as the CEO and chairman of Renault and Nissan, and also leads the Renault-Nissan Alliance. He earned the nicknames 'Le cost killer', 'ice breaker', and 'Mr. Fix it' due to his successful financial turnaround efforts at Nissan. Ghosn was born on 9th March 1954 in Porto Velho, Brazil, and completed his secondary studies at Collège Notre-Dame de Jamhour in Beirut, Lebanon. He graduated in engineering from École Polytechnique in 1978 and pursued post-graduate studies at the École des Mines de Paris. Ghosn began his career at Michelin & Cie in France and rose to the position of chief operating officer of Michelin’s South American operation by the age of 30, overseeing a $300 million business. 

In 1990, he became the CEO and chairman of Michelin North America, managing various aspects of the company's operations in South America. In 1999, Ghosn acquired a 36.8% stake in Nissan and subsequently joined the company as CEO, while retaining his positions at Renault. Upon his arrival at Nissan, the company was burdened with a debt of $20 billion and faced challenges with profitability. Ghosn implemented a three-year turnaround plan, which was achieved in just one year, taking Nissan from a loss of over $6 billion to a profit of $2.7 billion. This successful transformation solidified his reputation as a talented leader in the business world. Ghosn holds the distinction of being the first person to simultaneously lead two Fortune 500 companies.

Forbes magazine dubbed Ghosn as 'the hardest-working man in the brutally competitive global car business'. He is proficient in multiple languages, including Portuguese, English, French, and Arabic. Apart from his business ventures, Ghosn has invested in Ixsir, a vineyard with a focus on environmental benefits. Speculation arose about his potential candidacy in Lebanese politics, although he has not expressed any political ambitions. He has also made appearances in a documentary titled 'Revenge of the Electric Car' (2011) and had his life story documented in a comic book in Japan, titled 'The True Story of Carlos Ghosn'. Ghosn authored a bestselling book called 'Shift: Inside Nissan’s Historic Revival', shedding light on his experiences within the company.

Throughout his career, Ghosn has been acclaimed with numerous awards, such as being recognized as one of the 'Most Respected CEOs' by the CEO Quarterly Magazine in 2010 and receiving the 'Asia Business Leader of the Year' title from CNBC in 2011. In addition, he was inducted into the Japan Automotive Hall of Fame in 2010. Ghosn's legacy extends beyond his corporate achievements, as he remains a prominent figure in academic discussions, with his life and work serving as subjects for university theses and business essays.

His escape raised questions about Japan's judicial system and sparked debate over the fairness and human rights standards in the country's legal proceedings. Despite facing serious charges with a maximum penalty of 15 years in prison, Ghosn defended his actions as a response to perceived injustice and political persecution.

Carlos Ghosn was born on 9th March 1954 in Porto Velho, Brazil, to Jorge Ghosn and a Lebanese mother of Nigerian descent. Carlos is known for advocating sustainable transportation, leading the alliance to produce affordable zero-emission vehicles. In addition to his automotive roles, Carlos Ghosn holds positions on the international Advisory Council of Tsinghua University and the Strategic Council of Saint Joseph University in Beirut. Ghosn's plan proved successful, with Nissan posting record-breaking profits. He became Nissan's president in 2000 and CEO in 2001, the first foreigner to lead a major Japanese company. Ghosn focused on integrating cultures and achieving company objectives. By 2002, Nissan's profits continued to soar, and Ghosn's success was celebrated in Japan.

In 2005, Ghosn assumed the role of CEO at Renault while overseeing Nissan, solidifying his position as a leader in the automotive industry. He faced challenges at both companies, such as pressure on staff and market share concerns. Despite some setbacks, Ghosn continued to set ambitious goals for Renault's future success.

Ghosn announced the Commitment 2009 plan for Renault in 2006, aiming for increased sales and profit margins. He faced criticisms for his leadership style and the demanding nature of his positions at Renault and Nissan. However, Ghosn remained confident in his strategies and ability to lead both companies effectively.

Throughout his career, Ghosn demonstrated a talent for turnaround strategies and successful leadership in the automotive industry. Despite facing challenges and criticisms, he maintained a focus on achieving results and setting ambitious goals for the companies under his leadership.

context.text:
Carlos Ghosn, a notable automobile business tycoon, was born on March 9, 1954, in Porto Velho, Brazil, to Rose Jazzer and Jorge Ghosn, Lebanese immigrants. Growing up, he moved to Lebanon with his mother after his father was convicted of murder. Ghosn excelled in education, obtaining degrees in engineering from prestigious schools in Paris. By the age of 30, he was already a chief operating officer at Michelin in South America and later became the company's CEO in 1988.

In 1999, Ghosn acquired a significant stake in Nissan, and within a year, he had transformed the company, earning him the nickname "Mr. Fix-It." He restructured Nissan's debt into profit, becoming the first foreigner to lead the company in Japan. Known for his cost-cutting strategies, Ghosn closed factories under his management, leading to job losses but claiming it was necessary for the company's health.

However, in November 2018, Ghosn faced legal troubles when Japanese authorities arrested him over financial misconduct allegations, including underreporting his salary and misusing company funds. His wife, Carole Ghosn, and Greg Kelly were also implicated in the scandal. Feeling trapped by the Japanese justice system, Ghosn orchestrated a daring escape from Japan to Lebanon in a box disguised as musical equipment. This dramatic event was documented in the film "Carlos Ghosn: The Last Flight."

Following his escape, Ghosn has remained in hiding in Beirut, Lebanon. Despite his fugitive status, he has been vocal about his escape through a podcast, a new book titled "Broken Alliances: Inside the Rise and Fall of a Global Automotive Empire," and a documentary. Ghosn's wealth was estimated to be $120 million in 2021, and he continues to be a controversial figure, with some perceiving him as a successful entrepreneur and others as a fugitive avoiding justice.

Ghosn's escape involved assistance from individuals, including Michael and Peter Taylor, who were later sentenced to prison in Japan. It is unclear whether Ghosn will face repercussions for his actions in the future. As of now, reports suggest that Ghosn may potentially re-enter the automotive industry, possibly joining General Motors or Ford in the United States. His story has garnered significant attention, prompting various media outlets to explore and share his narrative.

context.title: Carlos Ghosn's Downfall at Nissan and the Aftermath
context.text: Carlos Ghosn is a prominent figure in the automotive industry who faced a downfall due to allegations of financial misconduct. At the time of his arrest on November 19, 2018, Ghosn was the chief executive officer of Renault SA and chairman of Nissan Motor Co. He was known for his role in saving struggling automakers in France and Japan. The shock of his arrest in Tokyo led to his detention in jail before being released on bail. Despite professing his innocence, Ghosn faced charges of under-reporting approximately $80 million in compensation and income at Nissan during the fiscal years 2010 to 2014. These allegations also included three counts of breach of trust, involving the use of foreign corporate entities to funnel funds for personal purposes like purchasing a yacht and supporting a technology investment fund for his son, Anthony. A significant development was Ghosn's escape from Japan to Lebanon in late 2019, where he found sanctuary. The aftermath of his flight has had a seismic impact on Nissan, particularly highlighting internal rifts concerning the level of integration with Renault. Ghosn's trial was scheduled to commence in the first half of 2020, with the charges carrying a maximum sentence of 10 years in prison.

context.title: Nissan CEO Carlos Ghosn story coming to Apple TV+
context.text:
Carlos Ghosn is a Brazilian-born former rock star businessman who served as the head of both Nissan and Renault. He is the subject of a new multi-part documentary series titled "Wanted: The Escape of Carlos Ghosn," which delves into his dramatic life story. Ghosn gained global influence and recognition for his role in the automotive industry, with Time magazine ranking him among the 15 most influential global business executives.

In 2019, Ghosn became embroiled in a scandal involving financial improprieties while in Japan. He made a daring escape from Japan to Lebanon with the help of a former Green Beret named Mike Taylor, who hid Ghosn in a music instrument box and facilitated his departure on a private jet. Ghosn sought refuge in Lebanon, his ancestral homeland, which has no extradition treaty with Japan. He denied the allegations against him, claiming that he fled injustice rather than justice.

The documentary series features interviews with key figures such as Louis Schweitzer, former CEO of Renault; Andy Palmer, former COO of Nissan; Arnaud Montebourg, former French minister of economy; Takashi Yamashita, former Japanese minister of justice; and Hiroto Saikawa, former Nissan CEO. Director James Jones secured access to Ghosn and his wife, Carole, for candid interviews, providing firsthand accounts of the events surrounding Ghosn's escape and legal battles.

The series explores Japan's legal system, highlighting criticisms of "hostage justice" and the high conviction rates based on forced confessions. Ghosn's case revolves around allegations of financial misconduct related to his compensation after a pay cut in 2009. He claims that the charges were fabricated as part of a power struggle within Nissan's boardroom, with officials wanting to prevent a potential merger with Renault.

Despite Ghosn's successful escape, his accomplices, such as Mike Taylor and his son Peter, faced legal consequences. Taylor was sentenced to two years in prison, while his son received a shorter sentence. They allege that Ghosn did not compensate them for their assistance in the escape, raising ethical and moral questions about leadership accountability.

The Ghosn saga serves as a cautionary tale of a leader who lost sight of ethical boundaries. Ghosn's sense of entitlement and desire for more compensation led to his downfall and tarnished reputation. The documentary series sheds light on the complexities of corporate power dynamics, the importance of transparency, and the consequences of unchecked authority in the business world.

Overall, Carlos Ghosn's story reflects a mix of ambition, betrayal, and controversy, illustrating the complexities of leadership and ethics in the corporate realm.

question: Tell me a bio of Mike Adenuga?
correct answer:
Chief Michael Adeniyi Agbolade Ishola Adenuga Jr, born on 29 April 1953, is a prominent Nigerian billionaire and the third richest person in Africa as of May 2021, with Forbes estimating his net worth at $6.2 billion. He is the founder of Globacom, Nigeria's second-largest telecom operator, which also operates in Ghana and Benin. Adenuga owns stakes in Equitorial Trust Bank and the oil exploration firm Conoil. His roots can be traced back to his parents, Oloye Michael Agbolade Adenuga Sr, a schoolteacher, and Omoba Juliana Oyindamola Adenuga, a royal Ijebu businesswoman.

Adenuga's educational journey took him from Ibadan Grammar School and Comprehensive High School, Aiyetoro, to acquiring degrees in Business Administration from Northwestern Oklahoma State University and Pace University, New York. His business acumen emerged early when he made his first million at 26 by selling lace and distributing soft drinks. His venture into the oil industry was marked by receiving a drilling license in 1990, and his company, Consolidated Oil, became the first indigenous company to find oil in commercial quantity in 1991.

The telecom industry saw Adenuga receiving a conditional GSM license in 1999, which was initially revoked but later reissued in 2003, laying the foundation for Globacom's success. He was acknowledged as the African Entrepreneur of The Year at the inaugural African Telecoms Awards in 2007. By 2015, Adenuga aimed to extend his telecommunications empire with a $600 million bid to acquire Comium Côte d'Ivoire.

His contributions and influence have been recognized with numerous honors, including the Grand Commander of the Order of the Niger (2012) by the Nigerian government, a Yoruba tribal chieftaincy as the Otunba Apesin of the Ijebu clan, and the decoration of Commander of the Legion of Honour by French President Emmanuel Macron in 2018. In 2019, he was listed as one of the Top 100 most influential Africans by New African magazine, underscoring his significant impact across various sectors on the continent.
